description: A creamy, hearty, and deeply flavorful dish where tender Dodo (amaranth leaves) are simmered in a thick, rich sauce made from groundnut paste. The slight bitterness of the greens is perfectly balanced by the nutty, savory creaminess of the groundnuts, creating a luxurious vegetable stew that is both nutritious and deeply satisfying.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This dish is a celebration of two Ugandan staples: the ubiquitous leafy green and the beloved groundnut. It transforms a simple vegetable into a main attraction, making a meal feel more substantial and special. It's a common way to ensure children eat their greens, as the creamy, flavorful sauce is very appealing. It represents the ingenuity of Ugandan cuisine in creating delicious, nutrient-dense meals from readily available ingredients.

ingredients.name: Fresh Dodo (Amaranthus) Leaves
ingredients.notes: About 10-12 cups, washed thoroughly and chopped

ingredients.name: Cooking Oil (optional)
ingredients.notes: Traditional for frying the base, but can be omitted for an oil-free version

steps.instruction: If using oil, heat it in a saucepan over medium heat. Saut√© the chopped onion until soft and translucent. If not using oil, use 2 tablespoons of water to 'water-fry' the onion until soft.
Add the chopped tomato to the pot and cook for 3-4 minutes until it softens and breaks down into a sauce.
In a separate bowl, gradually whisk the groundnut paste with about 2 cups of water until you have a smooth, lump-free, creamy liquid.
Pour the smooth groundnut mixture into the pot with the onions and tomatoes. Add the remaining 1 cup of water and stir to combine.
Bring the sauce to a gentle simmer. Let it cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Add the chopped dodo leaves to the simmering groundnut sauce. The pot will be full, but the leaves will wilt down.
Stir the dodo into the sauce, cover the pot, and let it cook for 5 minutes. The leaves will wilt and release water.

Uncover, add the salt, and stir well. Continue to simmer uncovered for another 5-10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the dodo is tender and the sauce has thickened to a creamy consistency that coats the leaves.

cooking_indicators.visual: The sauce is thick and creamy, and the leaves are dark green and tender.
cooking_indicators.texture: The greens should be soft but not mushy.

steps.instruction: Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. If the stew is too thick, add a little hot water to reach your desired consistency.
Serve hot as a main dish or a very substantial side.

serving_suggestions: This is a rich and hearty dish that can be a main course when served with a staple like Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Rice. It is so flavorful and protein-rich that it often doesn't need any other accompaniment, though it can be served with a side of avocado.
